article.title: Efficient Twitter Sentiment Classification using Subjective Distant Supervision

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 illustrate about the relationship between the subjectivity threshold and the number of tweets remaining after filtering?
choices: The number of tweets increases exponentially as the subjectivity threshold increases.
The number of tweets remains relatively constant regardless of the subjectivity threshold.
The number of tweets decreases exponentially as the subjectivity threshold increases.
There is no clear relationship between the subjectivity threshold and the number of tweets.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does Figure 2 depict regarding the relationship between accuracy and the subjectivity threshold?
choices: Accuracy decreases as the subjectivity threshold increases.
Accuracy remains constant regardless of the subjectivity threshold.
Accuracy increases as the subjectivity threshold increases.
There is no discernible relationship between accuracy and the subjectivity threshold.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the formula represent in the context of the article?
choices: Calculation of Support Vector Machine classification.
Calculation of Effective Word Score for a tweet.
Calculation of tweet subjectivity using TextBlob.
Calculation of tweet class probability using Naive Bayes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the comparison of training times presented in Figures 3 and 4?
choices: Training time for the baseline model is significantly lower than the proposed model for both Unigrams and Unigrams + Bigrams.
Training time for the proposed model with a subjectivity threshold of 0.8 is significantly higher than the baseline and 0.5 threshold models.
Training time for the proposed model with a subjectivity threshold is consistently lower than the baseline model for both Unigrams and Unigrams + Bigrams.
There is no significant difference in training time between the baseline and proposed models.
